response.answer_text: That’s hard to predict at the best of times, and more so because we don’t know what the outcome of the 2020 election will be. At the very least, one of the two major parties will go through some amount of contested primaries to find their candidate. If Trump loses in 2020, the Republicans will need to find a new candidate for 2024, just as they did in 2016. If the Democrats lose in 2020, they’ll need to do the same. A re-elected Trump wouldn’t be able to serve a further four years, so there’d be some question over who should succeed him, and depending on how things go for an elected Biden, there may be much the same question there. In the hypothetical event that the Democrats win but Biden only serves one term or less (due to his age), there’d be the question of whether whoever he names as Vice-President would be the automatic pick behind which the party falls in line, or whether there’s a sort of “changing of the guard” in the party as well. The type of candidate each party will gravitate towards is likely to be impacted by the 2020 outcome as well. A re-elected Trump will have another four years to shape the Republicans in his image, so while Mike Pence (as VP) would seem to be the logical next man up, there may be some challenge from a more “Trumpian” person. A Trump losing in 2020, particularly if he loses badly, may find that a lot of Republicans are very quick to say that they never knew him, so a much more “regular politician” type of candidate may surface. On the other side, there’s still the question of whether a genuinely progressively-minded Democrat could win, and that could flare up again 2024 depending on what happens this year.

Biden will not seek re-election and will endorse his Vice President, the first female Vice President the US has ever had, for President. The Republican Party will still be struggling to pick itself up and redefine itself after the resounding defeat in 2020 in which they lost the Presidential election and control of the Senate. They will understand that Trump tapped into a previously ignored portion of the electorate with his extreme rhetoric, but also acknowledge that that rhetoric pushed away moderate Republicans. Donald Trump, Jr. will try to mount a campaign from prison. The primary season will be ugly and the winner of the nomination will come out scathed and detested by half the party. The Democratic candidate will win and become the first female US President.
